data.title: Managing Water and Farmland Transitions in the San Joaquin Valley
data.meta_description: How can the San Joaquin Valley adapt to a future with less water? We’ve been researching this issue for the past seven years, and our new report presents highlights from we’ve learned, including a robust list of policy suggestions to help the valley weather—and make the most of—the coming changes.
data.text:
About the Authors

Ellen Hanak is vice president and director of the PPIC Water Policy Center and a senior fellow at the Public Policy Institute of California, where she holds the Ellen Hanak Chair in Water Policy. Under her leadership, the center has become a critical source of information and guidance for natural resource management in California. She has authored dozens of reports, articles, and books on water policy, including Managing California’s Water. Her research is frequently profiled in the national media, and she participates in briefings, conferences, and interviews throughout the nation and around the world. Her other areas of expertise include climate change and infrastructure finance. Previously, she served as research director at PPIC. Before joining PPIC, she held positions with the French agricultural research system, the President’s Council of Economic Advisers, and the World Bank. She holds a PhD in economics from the University of Maryland.

Andrew Ayres is a research fellow at the PPIC Water Policy Center and an assistant professor of economics at the University of Nevada, Reno. He is an environmental and natural resource economist focused on questions related to the design, development, and effectiveness of legal and economic institutions for managing the environment. His work often involves applied economic modeling and econometric analysis. Previously, he worked in Germany and the United States on projects to inform policies for climate change, energy, river restoration, and water pricing. He holds a PhD in economics and environmental science from the University of California, Santa Barbara, and a BA in economics from Pomona College.

Caitlin Peterson is associate director and research fellow at the PPIC Water Policy Center. She is an agroecologist whose research spans climate-smart agriculture, soil health, diversified cropping systems, agroecosystem resilience, and multi-benefit agricultural landscapes. In her previous work, she explored irrigation and soil ecosystem functions in California almond and tomato systems, crop-livestock integration in Brazilian soybean-beef systems, and small farmer adaptation to climate change in Colombia, Tanzania, and Ghana. As a consulting agroecologist, she led programs linking farmers across the US to emerging soil carbon marketplaces. She holds a PhD in ecology and an MS in international agricultural development from the University of California, Davis.

Alvar Escriva-Bou is an adjunct fellow with the PPIC Water Policy Center and an assistant professor with the Civil and Environmental Engineering Department and the Institute of the Environment and Sustainability at the University of California, Los Angeles. Before that, he was a senior fellow at the PPIC Water Policy Center, where his research explored integrated water, energy, and environmental resources management. While at PPIC, he examined the options and consequences of transitioning to groundwater sustainability in the San Joaquin Valley, analyzed California’s water accounting system, studied urban drought resilience, and investigated energy and climate policies related to water use, among other things. Previously, he worked as a civil engineer, managing and developing large infrastructure projects for local and regional governments and consulting firms in Spain. He holds a PhD and MS in water and environmental engineering and a BS in civil engineering from the Polytechnic University of Valencia in Spain, as well as an MS in agricultural and resource economics from the University of California, Davis.

Spencer Cole is a research associate with the PPIC Water Policy Center. His research interests include the role of water trading, groundwater banking, and reservoir management strategies in limiting groundwater overdraft as well as drought impacts on agricultural economics. Prior to joining PPIC, Spencer worked as a junior specialist and graduate student researcher for the University of California, Merced School of Environmental Engineering with a focus on agricultural modeling. Spencer holds a master’s degree in environmental systems and a BS in environmental engineering from the University of California, Merced.

Zaira Joaquín Morales is a research associate at the PPIC Water Policy Center. She provides critical research support to advance PPIC’s water and natural resource research agenda. Before joining PPIC, she worked for the Department of Animal Science at University of California, Davis, where she studied methane emissions from the state’s dairy sector. She holds a BS from University of California, Davis, where she participated in two research projects—on water resource management with a focus on issues in the Rio Grande basin and on soil science with a focus on groundwater recharge and its links to water quality.

Research Support

Shayan Kaveh is a science communicator at Sustainable Conservation. He holds a master’s degree from the Bren School of Environmental Science and Management at the University of California, Santa Barbara. His graduate research, conducted with the PPIC Water Policy Center and Conservation International, focused on the potential of retired croplands for habitat restoration and water resilience in California and Brazil. Previously, he managed international youth immersion programs focused on food justice and indigenous activism for students from the US and Latin America with the organization Amigos de las Americas. During his undergraduate studies, he contributed to ecology research at UC Davis’s Genomic Variation Lab, supporting eDNA studies on bat diets in the Sacramento Valley, post-fire pollination in the Sierra, and aquatic species surveys in the Suisun Delta.

Amy Mahler is an associate economist at RAND Corporation. She has a PhD in economics from the University of Southern California and over five years of experience managing and analyzing large, complex datasets in interdisciplinary research environments. During her graduate studies, she did research with the PPIC Water Policy Center on the implications of farmland transitions in the San Joaquin Valley for land prices and county revenues. Amy’s combination of applied econometric expertise and experience collaborating with diverse research teams is coupled with her interest in public finance and environmental issues.

Annabelle Rosser is a research analyst at Atlas Public Policy. Prior to that, she was a research associate at the PPIC Water Policy Center. Her research interests include drought mitigation and adaptation, environmental land use planning, and urban water management. Previously, she worked on projects assessing the vulnerability of low-income housing and community water systems to extreme heat and wildfire and evaluating green infrastructure development incentives while working as a graduate student researcher at the UCLA Luskin Center for Innovation. She holds a master’s degree in urban and regional planning from the Luskin School at University of California, Los Angeles, and a BA in international studies from the University of Chicago.

These and many other individuals from the valley and elsewhere generously gave of their time to participate in topical workshops on issues including dryland and water-limited cropping, air quality, solar development, and the Williamson Act.

Thanks also to the many colleagues who collaborated with us on the research and engagement activities for this project. Sarah Moffatt and Kristina Solberg from the Central Valley Community Foundation and Laura Ramos and Sarge Green from Fresno State’s California Water Institute provided overall help in guiding the project and convening valley stakeholders. We also thank research colleagues who co-authored other studies within this overall project, which laid the foundation for this report: Joy Collins, Mitchelle De Leon, Abigail Hart, Jaymin Kwon, Mark Lundy, Josué Medellín-Azuara, Cameron Pittelkow, Curtis Seymour, and Darcy Wheeles. Thanks also to Jeff Allenby and Hallah Elbeleidy of the Center for Geospatial Solutions at the Lincoln Institute of Land Policy for their contributions to the analysis of farm sizes in the region.

We also thank the following individuals whose reviews of an earlier draft of this report greatly improved this final version: Stephanie Anagnoson, Keali’i Bright, Kimberly Brown, Nick Clark, Aaron Fukuda, Sarge Green, Paul Gosselin, Abby Hart, Chris Hartley, Ann Hayden, Jelena Jezdimirovic, Jon Klassen, Jaymin Kwon, Cork McIsaac, Josué Medellín-Azuara, Jon Reiter, Zach Sugg, Dan Sumner, Emily Tibbott, and Lynette Ubois. Finally, special thanks to Sarah Bardeen, who provided expert editorial support, and to Jeff Mount and Brian Gray, who served as lead reviewers and provided overall guidance to the team. The authors alone are responsible for any remaining errors or omissions.

The California Strategic Growth Council’s (SGC) Climate Change Research Program (CCR) supports science to action, engaging both researchers and community partners in all stages of the research process to advance California’s climate change goals, with a focus on underserved communities. For more information, visit sgc.ca.gov/programs/climate-research. CCR is part of California Climate Investments, a statewide program that puts billions of cap-and-trade dollars to work reducing GHG emissions, strengthening the economy, and improving public health and the environment—particularly in disadvantaged communities. The cap-and-trade program also creates a financial incentive for industries to invest in clean technologies and develop innovative ways to reduce pollution. California Climate Investments projects include affordable housing, renewable energy, public transportation, zero-emission vehicles, environmental restoration, sustainable agriculture, recycling, and much more. At least 35 percent of these investments are located within and benefit residents of disadvantaged communities, low-income communities, and low-income households across California. For more information, visit www.caclimateinvestments.ca.gov.
